--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> > 
> > That is an unforeseen problem with co-evolution;
> you
> > can't easily tell how they are doing if the evolve
> > together.  I need to add some objective measure
> > because I like to know what's happening.  I won't
> use
> > that for evolution, just for observation.
> > 
> > 
> 
> We have a paper on measuring progress in competitive
> coevolution that you may find it useful:
> 
> http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/pub-view.php?RECORD_KEY(Pu
> bs)=PubID&PubID(Pubs)=113
> 
> This paper describes a way to check for increasing
> levels of
> dominance in a coevolution run.

Thanks, that's interesting and perhaps I will
eventually make use of the ideas.  In the present case
I can use a player who makes random moves as a
standard to evaluate progress.  Later, I will probably
code a perfect player as another standard to measure
against.

At the moment I have to debug my co-evolution code. 
The B population is not advancing at all, and the A
population much slower than before.  (when there was
only the A population vs. a random mover.)


=====
Mitchell Timin
